chapters.name: Women in Early American Political Life Before Suffrage
topics: How did women exercise political influence in the United States before they could vote?
What roles did women play in the American Revolution and early republic that were later erased from the record?
Why did the Constitution exclude women from political participation without explicitly naming them?
How did Abigail Adams's 'remember the ladies' letter reflect the gap between revolutionary ideals and political reality?
What forms of informal power — salons, petitions, moral reform — did women use to shape policy before suffrage?
How did the exclusion of women from early American politics compare to their status in other democracies at the time?

chapters.name: After the Vote: Why Suffrage Did Not Lead to Political Power
topics: Why did women's suffrage in 1920 not produce a wave of women running for or winning office?
How did political parties respond to women voters while still excluding women from leadership?
What structural barriers — from fundraising networks to party nominations — kept women out of office after suffrage?
Why did it take until 1932 for the first woman to be elected to the Senate, and why was she a widow filling her husband's seat?
How did the gap between voting rights and political representation reveal the limits of legal equality?
What lessons does the post-suffrage era hold for understanding why rights on paper do not automatically become power in practice?

chapters.name: The First Women Elected to the United States Congress
topics: Who was Jeannette Rankin, and what did her election to Congress in 1916 reveal about the conditions that allowed a woman to win?
Why were so many of the earliest women in Congress appointed or elected as widows of male incumbents?
How did Margaret Chase Smith break the pattern by building her own political career independent of her husband's legacy?
What obstacles did Shirley Chisholm face as the first Black woman in Congress, and how did she respond to them?
How did the 'Year of the Woman' in 1992 change the composition of Congress, and why did progress stall after it?
What do the stories of these early women in Congress reveal about which women were allowed to hold power and why?

chapters.name: How Political Parties Have Controlled Women's Access to Power
topics: How do party nomination processes and recruitment pipelines favor male candidates over equally qualified women?
Why do both major parties claim to support women candidates while their leadership structures remain disproportionately male?
What is the role of party gatekeepers in deciding which women get support and which are steered away from competitive races?
How has the Republican Party's relationship with women candidates shifted from the ERA era to the present?
How has the Democratic Party balanced promoting women candidates with protecting incumbents who are disproportionately men?
What would party structures look like if they were intentionally designed to produce gender-balanced slates?

chapters.name: Campaign Finance and the Gender Gap in Political Fundraising
topics: Why do women candidates consistently raise less money in the early stages of campaigns than men in equivalent races?
How does the donor class in American politics skew male, and what effect does that have on which candidates get funded?
What role have organizations like EMILY's List played in closing the fundraising gap for women?
How does the expectation of financial viability become a self-fulfilling barrier that discourages women from running?
Why does campaign finance research show that women who do raise competitive funds win at the same rate as men?
How would public financing of elections change the gender dynamics of who can afford to run for office?

chapters.name: How the Media Covers Women Running for Office
topics: Why do studies consistently show that media coverage of women candidates focuses more on appearance, family, and personality than policy?
How did media coverage of Hillary Clinton's 2016 campaign differ from coverage of male candidates with similar experience?
What is the 'double bind' in political media — where women are criticized for being too tough or too soft but never right?
How does social media amplify gendered attacks on women candidates in ways traditional media did not?
Why does reduced or biased media coverage of women candidates affect voter perceptions even when voters are unaware of the bias?
How did three decades of relentless media demonization of Hillary Clinton shape public perception of her before she ever ran for president?
What would equitable political journalism look like, and which outlets are closest to achieving it?

chapters.name: The Likability Trap: Why Women Candidates Are Judged Differently
topics: What research shows that voters apply different standards of 'likability' to women and men seeking the same office?
Why does ambition — a requirement for political office — trigger negative reactions when displayed by women candidates?
How do women candidates navigate the impossible expectation of being authoritative enough to lead but warm enough to be liked?
What role does implicit bias play in voter evaluations of women candidates, even among voters who believe in gender equality?
How have successful women politicians learned to manage the likability trap, and what does that management cost them?
Why does the likability standard persist despite decades of awareness, and what would it take to dismantle it?

chapters.name: Women of Color and the Double Bind in American Politics
topics: Why have women of color been historically underrepresented in elected office even compared to white women?
How did Shirley Chisholm's 1972 presidential campaign expose the intersection of racism and sexism in American politics?
What unique barriers do Black women face in fundraising, media coverage, and voter expectations when running for office?
How have Latina, Asian American, and Indigenous women navigated the specific challenges of representation in their communities and beyond?
Why did the 2018 and 2020 elections produce a historic wave of women of color in Congress, and how durable is that progress?
What does Kamala Harris's path to the vice presidency reveal about both the possibilities and the limits of intersectional political power?

chapters.name: The Glass Cliff: Why Women Lead When Failure Is Likely
topics: What is the glass cliff, and how does it differ from the more familiar concept of the glass ceiling?
Why are women disproportionately appointed to leadership positions in organizations and campaigns that are already in crisis?
How does the glass cliff operate in American politics — from party nominations in unwinnable races to crisis-era appointments?
What happens to women leaders who are placed on the glass cliff and fail — and how does their failure get attributed to gender rather than circumstance?
Why does research suggest that the glass cliff is not a conspiracy but a structural pattern rooted in how organizations think about risk and gender?
How can voters and institutions recognize when a woman's leadership appointment is genuine opportunity versus a setup for blame?

chapters.name: Women as Governors and Executives in the United States
topics: Why have so few women served as governors compared to their growing numbers in Congress?
What makes the path to a governorship structurally different from the path to a congressional seat, and how does that disadvantage women?
How did governors like Ann Richards, Christine Todd Whitman, and Janet Napolitano navigate gendered expectations of executive leadership?
Why is executive office often seen as more 'masculine' than legislative office, and how does that perception shape who runs?
What do the records of women governors reveal about whether women govern differently than men in practice?
How does the scarcity of women in governor's mansions affect the pipeline to presidential candidacies?

chapters.name: Women on the Supreme Court and the Judiciary
topics: Why did it take until 1981 for the first woman to be appointed to the United States Supreme Court?
How did Sandra Day O'Connor, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, Amy Coney Barrett, and Ketanji Brown Jackson each change the Court?
Why does the presence of women on the bench matter for how cases involving gender are argued and decided?
How has the federal judiciary's gender composition changed over time, and where do the biggest gaps remain?
What role did Ruth Bader Ginsburg play in building the legal framework for gender equality before she joined the Court?
How do confirmation hearings for women nominees differ from those for men, and what does that reveal about institutional bias?

chapters.name: Backlash Politics: Organized Resistance to Women in Power
topics: Why does every significant advance in women's political power produce organized backlash?
How did Phyllis Schlafly's campaign against the Equal Rights Amendment become a template for anti-feminist political organizing?
What forms does backlash take in contemporary politics — from policy rollbacks to targeted harassment of women in office?
How do online threats, doxxing, and coordinated abuse campaigns specifically target women officeholders and candidates?
Why do some women participate in movements that aim to limit women's political power, and how do scholars explain this?
What is the relationship between the rise of authoritarian populism and the targeting of women's political gains?

chapters.name: Where Gender Parity Exists in American Politics and Why
topics: Which states, cities, and political institutions have achieved or come closest to gender parity in elected office?
What specific conditions — term limits, multimember districts, recruitment programs — correlate with higher numbers of women in office?
Why do some state legislatures have near-parity while others remain overwhelmingly male?
How do local offices like city councils and school boards serve as pipelines to higher office for women?
What role do women's political organizations and training programs play in places where parity has been achieved?
What do the places that have achieved parity teach us about what is possible at the federal level?

chapters.name: How Other Democracies Achieved Political Parity for Women
topics: How did Rwanda become the first country in the world where women hold a majority of parliamentary seats?
What are gender quota systems, and why have over 100 countries adopted some form of them?
How do Scandinavian countries maintain consistently high levels of women's political representation without mandatory quotas?
Why has the United States resisted adopting the structural reforms that have increased women's representation in other democracies?
What is the difference between legislative quotas, voluntary party quotas, and reserved seats — and which ones work best?
What trade-offs come with quota systems, and how do countries that use them address concerns about merit and tokenism?

chapters.name: What Real Political Parity Would Require in the United States
topics: What structural changes to the American electoral system would be necessary to achieve lasting gender parity in office?
Why is parity in numbers not enough if women in office still face unequal influence, committee assignments, and leadership access?
How would campaign finance reform, redistricting, and ranked-choice voting each affect women's chances of winning?
What would it take to build a political culture where women running for office is unremarkable rather than exceptional?
How do childcare, caregiving responsibilities, and the structure of political work itself discourage women from seeking office?
Is gender parity in American politics achievable within the current system, or does the system itself need to be redesigned?
